entry.title: Complete Guide to Setting Up Story Reports in SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Objective: Learn how to configure Story Reports in SAP SuccessFactors with step-by-step instructions, best practices, and troubleshooting tips.

Table of Contents:

  1. Introduction.
  2. Licensing Overview.
  3. Pre-Requisites for Story Reports.
  4. IPS Sync Configuration.
  5. Settings Role-Based Permissions for Story Report.
  6. Creating a Story Report
  7. Styling and Chart Configuration
  8. Common Issues and Fixes
  9. Conclusion and Community Tips

Introduction:

SAP SuccessFactors Story Reporting is a modern reporting solution that transforms traditional HR reporting into interactive, visual, and real-time analytics. It empowers users to create dynamic reports with rich visualizations.

Story reports are recommended to use due to their various benefits as visualized in the image below:

Licensing Overview:

  • Story Reporting is included with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central.
  •  However, Workforce Analytics (WFA) and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) require separate licenses.
  • Note that live payroll data reporting is not supported in Story Reports and may require third-party tools like Query Manager.

Pre-Requisites for Story Reports:

  • Go to Upgrade Center and activate 'Stories in People Analytics'.
  • Configure Identity Authentication Service (IAS) and Identity Provisioning Service (IPS).
  • Ensure user sync from SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite to SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) via IPS.

IPS Sync Configuration:

  • To perform the IPS Sync, navigate to “Target Systems” to enable the newly configured SAP Analytics Cloud tenant.
    • Select the target system à select the “Edit icon” à  choose “Enable” and on the confirmation pop-up message that appears, choose “OK”.  The status of the tenant changes to “Enabled”. 
    • Navigate to “Source Systems” and select your source “SAP SuccessFactors tenant”.
    • Go to --> Jobs tab --> Read Job type à choose --> Run Now.
    • You can track the progress of the read job from Job Logs.
    • When the read job is completed, the user sync from SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite to SAP Analytics Cloud is completed.

Settings RBP for Story Report:

  •    Create Story: Full access to create, edit, share and manage reports.
  • Story Admin: Manage all Story Reports and access 'All Reports' tab

  • Manage Integration Tools → Allow Admin to Access ‘OData API through Basic Authentication’
  • Manage User → Data Access: User (Ensure user data visibility)

Developing a Story report:

  1. Selecting a database: Below I have selected ‘Job information’ and ‘Personal Information’ as a combination and selected the columns I need.
  2. Click on the ‘save’ on top of left corner and once done selecting the columns you need to click ‘Finish’ on bottom right corner of the screen.
  3. In the below image, I have dragged ‘Job Information’ and ‘Personal Information’, In personal information, I have selected ‘Gender’ to include the field in my report.

As “Job Information and Personal information” are effective dated entities, system will ask the ‘start date’ or ‘effective date’ from which you want the data to be reflected in the report.

Naming the database. Here, I have kept the database name as ‘Job Information’.

Once the database is saved system will redirect you to the below screen. You can ‘Insert’ and drag & drop title in the below screen:

Here, on the right side of the screen, we have 2 sections, Builder – is for configurational use and Styling – where cosmetics change can be done for respective charts.

Builder sections: Below is an overview sections available in Builder to use while developing your story report.

  • Here we have data source names, in charts we have various options to select from, as per requirement.
  • Below I have selected a “Bar/Column” chart where I can select its orientation.
  • Then we have measures and dimensions which I have explained below in details.

To use various charts, we need to define ‘Measure’ and ‘Dimensions’. Which are important to build a story report.

  1. Measure: A measure is a quantitative value that you can perform calculations on, such as sums, averages, counts, or percentages.
    • Examples: Number of employees, Average performance rating, Total compensation, Headcount.
    • Usage: Measures are typically used in charts and tables to show trends, comparisons, or aggregations.
  2. Dimension: A dimension is a qualitative attribute used to categorize or group data. It provides context for measures. 

    Styling: In styling we have various features available as highlighted in left side of the below image. Widgets and legends are basic and most use features in styling section.

    • Widgets – where you can customize background colour, borders – style, width etc
    • Legends- where name of the dimensions are displayed, you can decide where to place your legend with options as – above, below and beside charts.

    Configuring a simple chart: Below, I have created a Bar/column chart, which is vertical in orientation. Measure is ‘Count’ (Employee count) and dimension is ‘Gender’. Colour for the bar/column chart can also be customised as per requirement. In the example, the instance is using 4 genders – Male(M), Female(F), undeclared(D)and unknown(U)

Common Issues and Fixes:

  1. For a user to be able to create Story Reports, their user information must be successfully synchronized to the SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) instance (as discussed earlier in the blog) and be assigned the appropriate RBP access. When this does NOT occur, the user is unable to create a new Story report or when creating a new story report, the webpage is stuck in a blank loading screen, or errors are displayed.
  2. Troubleshooting common issues via check tool: 
    1. SACDuplicateEmailValidationCheck:  
      • Purpose: This check identifies duplicate or unmapped email addresses in the system that are not linked to any user configured for Stories in People Analytics.
      • Email addresses are the primary key for user identification in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC).
      • Duplicate or unmapped emails can cause login failures, reporting issues, or data inconsistencies in People Analytics.
    2. SACUserValidationCheckWithQuickFix
      1. Purpose: This check validates whether a user is correctly configured for Stories in People Analytics and offers a Quick Fix option if issues are detected.
      2. Ensures that users have the correct roles, permissions, and configurations to access Stories in People Analytics.
      3. Reduces dependency on manual troubleshooting by providing automated fixes.
    3. SACUserValidationCheck
      1. Purpose: This check verifies that a user record exists for Stories in People Analytics.
      2. Confirms that the user is present in the system, which is the first step before assigning roles or permissions.
      3. Prevents errors when granting access to People Analytics features.
         

    4. SAC connection error: In Check Tool when checked if the user exists in SAC and can see below error:

      1. The availability of the selected user couldn’t be confirmed for People Analytics, because of a connection error.
      2. To fix this we need to "Refresh SF Live Connection" and “x509 certificates” from Provisioning under "Configurations for Stories in People Analytics".

Conclusion:

Following these steps ensures a successful setup of Story Reports in SAP SuccessFactors. Share your experiences and tips in the comments to help others in the community.

entry.title: Use Employment Differentiator for Translation Limitation on People Profile and Spotlight Header
entry.content:
From customer implementation, we observe that the language translation on the spotlight header would stay in default language English instead of the expected translation version (f.e. French) by Language switch via user Settings.  Know issue was reported by the SAP Note below.

2648773 - Position Title and Department and Division are shown in English on Employee Profile header - Employee Profile

First, the French Translation has maintained in the Globe context menu for the Position. From the screenshots below, after switch the user language to French,  the translation for these Job and Org fields are displayed properly in Full Spotlight "Organization" Category Card.  However, the same French translation could not be synced to the Spotlight Header or Full Profile Header part where they are still displayed in English.

Secondarily, these Organization and Job Information fields displayed on Spotlight and Header Areas are coded with no feasibility to customize. 

  

 

As a workaround, we could introduce to use Employment Differentiator.  This differentiators function provides flexibility to display defined or customized three fields from JobInfo for all users no matter whether the user has multiple employments or not. You don't need to have prerequisite like multiple employments, concurrent employments, global assignment etc. This could be considered as "An Addition" for Customization. 

In my practice below to display French version of Division, Department and Job Classification in Spotlight and Full Profile Header. In general, we need to create an Employment Differentiator object in Manage Data. An Employment Differentiator allow maximum 3 custom fields by design. We can leverage these 3 custom fields to link to standard or custom fields from Job Information Model HRIS Elements (ONLY). Then, the values (picklist configured for HRIS elements) can be displayed accordingly by this Employment Differentiator. Here comes the key configuration steps: 

Step 1 - Create Picklist for "JobClass_FR", "Division_FR", and "Dept_FR" respectively. Set these 3 picklist values directly as the French version of translation (These can be fetched from Manage Position). 

Step 2 - In Business Configuration, create custom-string for "Division FR", "Dept FR" and "Job Class FR" and set the picklist we configuration in Step 1 to the object respectively. 

Step 3 - Set Permission Roles for the custom-strings created in Step 2 for both System Admin and Employee Self Service. The proper role settings make sure both New Hire and Existing Employee will not miss to select the value defined in picklist as mandatory. 

This is important to remember that If the value used for the differentiator is not available in the current Job Information record, the value will not be displayed in People Profile.

Step 4 - To adopt Employment Differentiator, assignmentDisplayHeader should be enabled in Business Configuration -> Employee Profile -> Standard. 

In addition, please make sure RBP settings are configured for both System Admin and Employee Self Service to View/Edit Employee Data -> Employee Profile -> ASSIGNMENTDISPLAYHEADER.

Step 5 - Set up the Employment Differentiator object to connect the dots. It is named "Org Job FR" in my practice and its 3 custom fields point to the 3 custom-string created in Step 2. Jobinfo is only the supported HRIS element reference by design.

Step 6 - To Switch ON the Employment Differentiator, go to Configuration Latest People Profile -> General Settings -> Choose the Name created in Step 5 from the dropdown list of Choose Employment Differentiator.  Click the Save button.

Do not forget to Refresh Assignment Header and Refresh General Display Name from the Company System and Logo Settings to activate it.  After both HRIS Sync jobs are Completed from Scheduled Job Monitoring, it's time to check the final result. 

Step 7 - Final Check. The French Version can be displayed on header no matter which language setting is selected. 

Last but not least, Employment Differentiator could be used not only for translation workaround, but for dispalying any additional job information as well.

More details could be referred in the following SAP Help link. 

Adding Employment Differentiators To Indicate Multiple Employments

2786331 - Employee Central - Employment Differentiators Indicator

Thanks for your reading and hope this blog is helpful!

entry.title: Enhancing Successfactors Alert Message With Images Through HTML
entry.content:
Scenario

With the scenario as ours in consideration where the business required an image and a footer on already existing birthday alert message for users company wide.

The scenarios might differ company wise or client wise but the very basic method or process of fulfilling this requirement remains the same widely.

Alert Message Configuration 

Here we will be discussing the pre-requisite and configurations required for a header and a footer for our system triggered alert message and possible issues along with their solutions that we might face post alert trigger.

Pre - Requisites

  • We should have admin rights on Successfactors preferably Manage Data and Alert Message permissions.
  • We should have a One Drive and Outlook access for uploading our header and footer and validating our email alert respectively.
  • Thirdly, we shall be able to host or upload the images which we want to use as a header and a footer for our alert message (in our case we have uploaded it on a One Drive folder) as we will be using the One Drive link of that picture in our HTML code.
  • We can also host the images online through free available tools and then use that link in our html.

Configuration 

  • Create an alert message as per your message content.
  • Use the below mentioned html code for the header/footer section where you want the pictures to appear in the alert message as per attached image.


<html>
<body>
<h2></h2>
<img src="Use The Link Within These Inverted Commas Mentioned In The Third Point Under Pre-Requisites Heading" width="100" height="50">
</body>
</html>​
  • Adjust the width and height as per your requirement.
  • Please note that if you want to include both header and footer (like in our case), the mentioned html code must be used separately first in the header area (where you want your header to appear) and then in the footer section (where you want your footer to appear) with the width/height adjustments as per the requirements.
  • We can also use below code for center alignment of the images,
<h2></h2>
<div style="text-align: center;">
<img src="Use The Link Within These Inverted Commas Mentioned In The Third Point Under Pre-Requisites Heading" width="500" height="333">
</div>​
  • Now initiate the alert message and check your email for your required header and footer.

Incase we receive an email with below attached error in your header/footer or in an image. The possible reasons might be,

  1. We might have made a mistake in copying the link.
  2. The image might have been removed from the folder you uploaded on.
    If you are sure about the above two points then the most probable reason is that,
  3. Your organization has blocked the https images on your email. In this case you can co-ordinate with your internal services team or follow the below Microsoft blog for resolution.
    The Linked image cannot be displayed error - Outlook | Microsoft Learn
  4. Get the https images allowed for your organization and you will start receiving the email with the recent made changes. 

Conclusion

Concluding, we can use different html tags to enhance the alert triggers that are being initiated from SuccessFactors. With a little tweaking and understanding of html tags we can actually cater the business requirements that can standout.

entry.title: SAP BTP for HR at SAP Connect and Success Connect 2025 summary - bigger and better than ever
entry.content:
Come see SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) at this year’s SAP Connect / Success Connect event in Las Vegas! Due to the ever-increasing interest in SAP BTP topics and our sessions in prior years having standing-room only attendance, SAP BTP has more sessions than ever before! We even have for the first time ever, not one, but two hands-on-labs!

Related: For more information about SAP BTP presence outside of HCM, see these two articles:

  • Success Connect: Your People Deserve More Than Just Software - They Deserve Success - SAP Community
  • SAP Connect 2025: The Ultimate Business Transformation Experience - SAP Community

 

SAP BTP topics for 2025

This year’s SAP BTP for HR experience at SAP Connect is all about more. More business scenarios, more technology, more platform - more BTP! This year’s topics include customer favorites such as integration, extensibility and automation as well as numerous SAP SuccessFactors product-led sessions about how SAP BTP helps them deliver better solutions making it easier for customers to streamline HCM processes. Additionally, as we see an increase in technical audience members, we’ll be featuring slightly more
technical product deep dives by the product teams (also a first for us!).

Demos and hands-on labs

Demo-station demo: Automate new hire equipment ordering during onboarding, featuring Integration Suite Advanced Event Mesh

We’re showcasing two demos at the “Integration and Extension with SAP BTP” demo station. The first is our popular Automate new hire equipment ordering during onboarding demo which shows SAP Integration Suite’s Advanced Event Mesh event-driven integration capabilities to provide automated equipment ordering. This dramatically reduces the amount of time a people manager spends ordering equipment as well as requesting access to systems and data. If you missed this demo in Lisbon last year, then this is your chance!  Included are:

  • See how we used SAP Signavio Process Intelligence to analyze onboarding processes to identify key areas to address inefficiencies: hiring manager ordering of equipment, waiting for responses from people via email
  • SAP Integration Suite and advanced event mesh which offers real-time triggering of data synchronization based on SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central event triggers
  • An example app an IT department can create to offer pre-bundled packages of equipment to make it easier for managers to pick equipment, and to standardize offerings
  • One-click approvals by the hiring manager, powered by SAP Build 
  • Automatically submitting equipment selection to SAP Ariba guided buying via SAP Integration Suite
  • Notifications pushed to the task center for the hiring manager via SAP Build
  • Automatic submission of support tickets to SAP Service Cloud for manual tasks like requesting access to systems and data


Demo-station demo: Create a mobile app with SAP Build demo and hands-on lab

Additionally, we’re showing our brand new Create a mobile app with SAP Build demo which is specifically designed for more technical HRIS audiences in collaboration with the SAP SuccessFactors team. 

This demo is also the basis of two, 75-minute hands-on labs we’re offering this year which are sure to sell out! The lab will walk non-technical novices and intermediate technical knowledge people (non-developers, IT and HRIS are our target audience) on how to use SAP Build to quickly and easily create a mobile app with SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central people data to offer location-specific benefits for a field office – all with no coding, using SAP Build’s powerful drag-and-drop development interface. We’ll have product experts from the SAP Build team presenting and explaining to the audience the different capabilities of SAP Build in a follow-the-presenter format from their own workstations in live SAP Build environments so everyone will be able to walk away with direct product knowledge of what’s possible.
Included in the session:

  • Overview of the low-code SAP Build environment
  • Overview of various content types, controls, functions available
  • Adding content and configuring to the controls
  • Using an integration to SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central for people data
  • Accessing benefits information in the employee profile via API
  • Customizing the look and feel of the app
  • Testing the app and deployment

View the hands-on lab in the event catalog: Hands-on lab: Creating a custom mobile app for HR using SAP Build solutions (limited capacity) | HCM1677

There’s also quick overview videos of both these demos on the SAP.com/btp-for-HR page as well!

 

SAP BTP-led sessions

Integration sessions


Maximizing HCM process efficiency with integration through SAP BTP | HCM1665

Discover how SAP Business Technology Platform and SAP Integration Suite enable integrations for SAP SuccessFactors HCM, automating tasks and processes. Explore third-party integration use cases, such as recruiting, onboarding, and data collection, and strategies for connecting hybrid landscapes, including legacy on-premises and third-party systems as well as event-driven integrations.

How to use event-driven integration to collaborate in real time | HCM1682

Explore how SAP Integration Suite advanced event mesh can use business events from SAP SuccessFactors solutions such as SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central to push data to other internal or external systems in real-time. See firsthand how you can use this capability to trigger immediate actions, such as when an employee is hired or terminated.



Application development and extensibility sessions

Increasing employee efficiency with automation capabilities in SAP BTP | HCM1671

Explore automation capabilities in SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) that can streamline your HCM processes. From recruiting and onboarding to document management, SAP BTP can help you reduce errors in manual data entry and make your employees happier by reducing repetitive and mundane tasks through automation and workflows.

Using SAP Build to extend your SAP SuccessFactors solutions | HCM1463

Standardized business processes have come a long way, but every company still has a few things it does differently from everybody else. SAP Build solutions can help extend your human capital management solutions to address your specific business needs. See firsthand how to create low-code/no-code apps that boost end-user adoption and efficiency.

 

SAP SuccessFactors-led technology sessions including SAP BTP


These SAP SuccessFactors product expert-led sessions discuss how SAP BTP solutions help SAP SuccessFactors deliver better solutions to our customers as well as ways customers may not be aware of how they can use SAP BTP today with their existing SAP SuccessFactors solutions.

 

AI Technology, use cases and innovation

Road map and vision: AI in SAP SuccessFactors HCM | HCM1451

Look at SAP’s AI strategy and planned AI innovations in SAP SuccessFactors HCM. See what’s on the AI road map for HCM and get insights into SAP’s responsible, real-world AI approach. AI-driven capabilities such as the Joule copilot, AI agents, and the mobile experience with Joule  enhance employee experience, adaptability, and productivity

Unlocking and extending the Joule copilot with Joule Studio | HCM1571

Experience how Joule Studio allows you to create and deploy custom Joule agents and skills that improve efficiency across SAP and third-party systems and enhance your HR experience. Learn about prerequisites and how to get started, and find out how the agent builder capability in Joule Studio can empower you to create your own intelligent agents.

Everything you need to know about AI agents for HCM | HCM1468

AI agents are "smart teammates" that can observe, plan, and act, often without human intervention. Get a first look at some of the Joule Agents in the HCM road map, such as those for performance and goals, HR service, and people intelligence. Learn how agents can automate complex workflows, augment human capabilities, and drive efficiency.

 

 

Employee experience via integration and extensibility

Drive productivity by integrating and extending your HCM solutions | HCM1081

Discover how our recent innovations around integration and extension can help transform your business operations and enhance the user experience. You can use these technologies to integrate and extend your SAP SuccessFactors HCM portfolio with SAP Business Technology Platform.

Enhancing people profiles with SAP Business Technology Platform | HCM1520

See firsthand how you can enhance the latest people profile using SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), with an exclusive preview of advanced features slated for early adopter release in the second half of 2025. Learn how to extend people profiles to meet your organization’s needs and boost the user experience.

 

 

Technology and administration


Road map and vision: Application and technology foundation | HCM1030

Explore the latest innovations and enhancements in the technology and application foundation of SAP SuccessFactors solutions, including the SAP Business Data Cloud solution, Joule Studio, security, integration, extensibility through SAP Build solutions, and more. See demos and gain insights into what we have planned for our upcoming releases.

Simplifying your system administration to maximize business continuity | HCM1106

Explore innovative solutions to streamline system configuration and administration of your SAP SuccessFactors solutions. Gain practical tips on how your organization can modernize infrastructure management and boost efficiency with powerful administrative capabilities.

Fortifying together: Best practices for partner and customer security | HCM1061

Explore collaboration strategies and best practices for bolstering security across partners and customers. Discover how collective efforts and aligned practices can mitigate risks and build resilient ecosystems. Don't miss this opportunity to strengthen your security framework and foster trust among your business network.

 

If you haven’t attended Success Connect in the past (now SAP Connect), this year is the time to come to see all the great BTP content and sessions! Learn more about SAP Connect on the event page.

entry.title: Enhancing Background Information Integration Across Recruiting, Onboarding, and Employee Central
entry.content:
Introduction

Today, I would like to share a solution that addresses a common challenge in background information integration (e.g., outside work experience, education, languages, certificates, and more) across SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting, Onboarding, and Employee Central (EC).

By introducing both the SAP standard design and an enhanced solution I implemented, I aim to highlight:

  • The limitations of the current standard design
  • Why SAP should consider improving this area
  • How organizations can achieve a low-cost enhancement for a more seamless process

Background

A customer required a seamless experience for collecting candidate background information. Ideally, the process should follow these steps:

  1. Application Stage: Candidates provide background information (outside work experience, education, language proficiency, and certificates) when submitting a job application.
  2. Onboarding Stage: Once an offer is accepted, candidates can review and update their data in Onboarding and add additional background information which is not required to fill in recruiting phase (e.g., memberships).
  3. Employee Central Integration: This background data should flow automatically and consistently into SuccessFactors Employee Central (EC).
  4. Employee Self-Service (ESS): Background information should remain editable via EC workflows after hiring.

Unfortunately, this seemingly simple and logical process is not fully supported in the standard SuccessFactors design due to the following limitations:

  1. Background elements in the candidate profile can only be synchronized directly to the Employee Profile without through onboarding phase. Please refer to KBA: 2233525 - How is the system working with sm-mapping? - Recruiting Management.
  2. Standard background elements cannot be configured in the New Hire Data Collection template. This means background data cannot be reviewed or updated during the Onboarding phase.
  3. EC workflows cannot be configured for standard background elements. Typically, MDF-based background information is required in order to enable workflows.  Please refer to KBA: 2829360 - Workflows and Business Rules - Are they Supported for EP Portlets?

Workaround

To enable ESS workflows and Onboarding Data Collection, it is recommended to use MDF-based background information.   The MDF-based background objects should be configured to mirror the field settings of the standard background elements. This ensures consistency of data structures across modules.   To maintain alignment between the two, use Integration Center to perform a one-way synchronization from MDF-based background information to the standard background elements.

However, this introduces a new challenge:
How can we keep the standard background information blocks (required by Talent Development modules) aligned with the MDF-based data? The key difficulties are:

  1. Automatic synchronization of MDF data into background information blocks.
  2. Avoiding duplicate entries: Each background record is uniquely identified by backgroundElementId, which is auto-generated by the system. If not matched, the system treats incoming records as new ones. Since Integration Center jobs cannot capture responses (as in CSV imports), careful design is required to prevent duplicate records.

Solution

The solution involves using Integration Center to auto-sync MDF-based background information into Employee Profile (EP) background elements for new hires. This is a one-time sync executed after the employee becomes an EC user.

 

Key Design Points

  • Timing of Integration

    • Synchronization should occur only after Manage Pending Hire is completed and the Employee Conversion job has run. At this point, the Employee Profile is active and actionable.
    • Integration criteria should be based on the OnboardingHireStatus in the Process Table, combined with a recent hire date filter (e.g., within the past week). This ensures only newly hired employees are included.

 

  • Handling Multiple Records (e.g., Education)

    • When working with multiple education records, the challenge is that Integration Center cannot navigate from a child entity back to the parent object.
    • To address this, a custom user field is created to automatically populate the new hire’s User ID using an onsave Business Rule.
    • With this field in place, the integration can navigate from the child entity (e.g., Education) to the User/ONB2Process table, applying the required filters.

  • Removed Duplicated Background Info via Provisioning Job

    • Enable Provisioning Job to remove the duplicated background info record which is inserted by API or Integration Center accidentally and unexpected. Please refer to KBA: 2790234 - Delete Duplicate Background Data

Conclusion

While the standard SAP SuccessFactors design does not currently provide a seamless end-to-end flow for background information, this MDF-based enhancement with Integration Center offers a practical, low-cost workaround.
It enables:

  • A smoother transition of data across Recruiting, Onboarding, and Employee Central
  • The ability for employees to manage and update their background information through ESS workflows
  • Continued support for Talent Development modules by keeping standard background blocks aligned This solution demonstrates how thoughtful enhancements can bridge gaps in the current design and deliver the seamless user experience customers expect.

entry.title: SAP Connect 2025: The Ultimate Business Transformation Experience
entry.content:
Hello, SAP Community!

I'm thrilled to introduce you to something completely new in the SAP events landscape: SAP Connect 2025, our groundbreaking annual event for business leaders that highlights how businesses maximize their SAP investments and accelerate transformation.

You've invested significantly in SAP solutions across your organization. Your CHRO relies on SAP SuccessFactors for talent management, your CPO uses SAP Ariba to optimize procurement, your CMO leverages SAP Customer Experience solutions to drive engagement, your CFO depends on SAP S/4 Finance to keep the business running, and your COO manages supply chain demand with SAP Integrated Business Planning. But here's the challenge every C-suite leader faces—how do you connect your organization’s disconnected landscape so you can move beyond implementation to true business transformation?

 

 

Beyond Software: Your Partner in Business Success

While SAP is fundamentally a software company, our mission extends far beyond delivering technology. We empower business leaders, whether you're a CHRO building world-class teams, a CPO driving procurement excellence, a CMO creating customer loyalty, a CFO optimizing financial performance, or a COO ensuring operational excellence, to achieve transformational business outcomes.

The reality is that technology alone cannot be the sole factor in innovation. It's the strategic implementation and utilization of that technology that is aligned with your specific business challenges and opportunities that creates measurable value. SAP Connect 2025 is designed around this fundamental truth:

Your business outcomes are our primary measure of achievement.

 

 

The Reality Check: Where Most Organizations Stand Today

The 2025 C-Suite survey by Thomson Reuters Institute identified the following as the key challenges that currently hinder the effectiveness of enabling functions within organizations:

  1. Ineffective data and information flows between different departments
  2. Time-consuming compliance and reporting tasks
  3. Staffing and resourcing challenges, and
  4. Poor data quality and structure.

 

Do any of them sound familiar? Regardless of your role and vertical, these challenges continue to be roadblocks to achieving short- and long-term success for today’s businesses.

 

 

What Makes SAP Connect Different: Connect Everything, Achieve Anything

If you’re a seasoned business leader with SAP events, you’ll notice that it’s looking a little different this year. Unlike the previous years of offering separate events for each department, SAP Connect is now one unified event with five specialized experiences, each designed for a specific department. This clearly illustrates the connection between SAP Business Suite and how these solutions work together to drive enterprise-wide value.

  • Success Connect: Transform your workforce with the latest HR solutions | Register
  • Spend Connect: Optimize business and realize opportunities  | Register
  • Customer Experience Connect: Drive customer loyalty and build relationships  | Register
  • Finance Connect: Revolutionize financial operations to beat market volatility  | Register
  • Supply Chain Connect: Build resilient, intelligent supply chain networks | Register

Each Connect event delivers deep, dedicated content while maintaining a connection to the broader SAP Business Suite ecosystem. You'll walk away with concrete strategies tailored to your specific business challenges.

 

 

How does the SAP Business Technology Platform fit in SAP Connect?

It couldn’t be more fitting! Like this year’s theme of ‘Connect everything. Achieve anything’, SAP Integration Suite within SAP Business Technology Platform is the answer to cross-organization connectivity. Integrating your across SAP and third-party applications allows you to build, extend and automate with SAP Build￼more to bring value to the business. Also, with prebuilt integration packages and AI-assisted features, the ROI can be achieved more efficiently. And of course, we can't forget about AI! With SAP Joule tailored for your developers' needs, you can generate code, automate processes, design intuitive UIs, and build custom agents using AI. 

Take these verified SAP BTP use cases as an example:

 

  1. Create a custom mobile app for HR using SAP Build: 

    1. Business challenge: Complex processes and access to business applications for field-based and deskless employees. Error-prone processes with little visibility into data and insights
    2. Business values: Reduced implementation time with low-code development tools. Improved employee efficiency by streamlining and automating processes
    3. Customer example: CITIC Pacific Mining Management Pty Ltd. integrated SAP SuccessFactors applications, then used SAP Build to automate document digitization in a safe and compliant way via their mobile web app. This eliminated manual information collection, entry, and validation, keeping the data always up-to-date and compliant. This allowed CITIC to save up to $A300,000 annually on worker productivity.

  2. Expedite your financial close with intelligent automation:

    1. Business challenge: Reliance on error-prone e-mail and spreadsheet tasks for financial closing, paired with time-consuming repetitive tasks.
    2. Business values: Automated tasks with SAP-curated agents and document task completion that decreases errors and strengthens data validation and verification.
    3. Customer example: De Agostini Publishing achieved significant automation improvements in its vendor invoice processing. Over 91% of PO-referred invoices are now processed automatically, and approximately 500 hours are saved per month through its SAP-based solution. The company successfully processes 54,000 paper-based vendor invoices annually while achieving 90-95% text capture accuracy from PDF invoices.

If you're interested, check out the full list of our verified SAP BTP use cases here.

 

 

What's Coming Next in This Series

In the next blog posts, I’ll explore the five Connect experiences and highlight some of the sessions while providing a strategic framework for maximizing your SAP Connect experience and translating insights into business value. But don’t let that stop you from registering and checking out the event agenda to see all the sessions offered at Connect here!

Here’s also a blog from my colleague @rnoia  on SAP BTP for HR at SAP Connect and Success Connect 2025 summary.

Stay tuned for Part 2!

entry.title: Implementing custom compensation statements
entry.content:
Unlike standard statements, creating a custom statement that meets all client requirements while also looks visually appealing is quite an innovative activity.

 It involves detailed break-up of every pay component and fields, while also reflecting company’s identity through custom logos, various colors, and desired formatting.

Now, let's explore the code.

Declaring parameters name to be used in statements

<xsl:param name="statementTitle"/>
	<xsl:param name="customLogoURL"/>
	<xsl:param name="companyLogoURLParam"/>
	<xsl:param name="companyName"/>
	<xsl:param name="DEPARTMENT"/>
	<xsl:param name="moneyFormat"/>
	<xsl:param name="amountFormat"/>
	<xsl:param name="percentFormat"/>
	<xsl:param name="userLocaleSpecificMoneyFormat"/>
	<xsl:param name="userLocaleSpecificAmountFormat"/>
	<xsl:param name="userLocaleSpecificPercentFormat"/>
	<xsl:param name="userLocaleSpecificBonusPercentFormat"/>
	<xsl:param name="userLocaleSpecificDecimalFormatter"/>
	<xsl:param name="EMPID"/>
	<xsl:param name="FIRSTNAME"/>
	<xsl:param name="userName"/>
	<xsl:param name="LASTNAME"/>
	<xsl:param name="DIVISION"/>
	<xsl:param name="DISPLAYNAME"/>
	<xsl:param name="LOCATION"/>
	<xsl:param name="managerFirstName"/>
	<xsl:param name="managerLastName"/>
	<xsl:param name="TITLE"/>
	<xsl:decimal-format name="defaultDecimalFormatter" decimal-separator='.' grouping-separator=',' />
	<xsl:decimal-format name="decimalFormatterDotComma" decimal-separator=',' grouping-separator='.' />
	<xsl:decimal-format name="decimalFormatterSpaceComma" decimal-separator=',' grouping-separator=' ' />

 Declare company logo "we have to use company URL"

<xsl:variable name="companyLogoURL">
		<xsl:text disable-output-escaping="yes"><![CDATA[abc.jpg]]></xsl:text>
	</xsl:variable>
  • For adding company logo URL in custom statements, we must raise an incident to SAP.

Declare variables in compensation statements 

	<xsl:template match="/sf-compensation">
	<!--Variable Defnitions go here-->
		<xsl:variable name="empFirstName" select="./comp-plan-entry/comp-plan-entry-firstname"/>
		<xsl:variable name="empLastName" select="./comp-plan-entry/comp-plan-entry-lastname"/>
		<xsl:variable name="userId" select="./comp-plan-entry/comp-plan-entry-userid"/>
  • If any custom field is created, then you can also use this approach –
 <xsl:variable name="customID" select="./comp-plan-entry/comp-custom-data/comp-custom-field[@id='customID']"/>

 To Declare variable in Variable Pay Statements

 <xsl:variable name="customField1" select="vp-bonus-assignment/vp-custom-data/vp-custom-field[@id='customField1']"/>
    <xsl:variable name="customField2" select="vp-bonus-assignment/vp-custom-data/vp-custom-field[@id='customField2']"/>
    <xsl:variable name="customField3" select="vp-bonus-assignment[1]/vp-bonus-payout-item-list/vp-bonus-payout-item/vp-custom-data/vp-custom-field[@id='customField3']"/>
  • The first variable “customField1” is referring to variable present to ENTRY Level
  • The second variable “customField2" is referring to variable present on ASSIGNMENT Level.
  • The third variable “customField3 is referring to variable present on BUSINESS GOAL Level.

Declare all the CSS for the table, rows & column whichever is to be used in statements

.headerdetail {
font-size: 9pt;
font-family: Calibri;
margin-left:30px;
margin-top:20px;
margin-bottom:20px;
}
  • Here. headerdetail is a table used to display name and is explaining how CSS is defined for this table used in the statement
  • Font-size is 9, font- family is Calibri, Margin from left is 20 px , Margin from top os 20 px and from bottom its 20px.

Declaring a row 

<table class="headerdetail" valign="center" align="left" border="1px solid black" cellspacing="0" style="width:60%; border:1px solid black;padding-top:10px;border-collapse: collapse">
          <tr>
          <td valign="center" style="text-align:left; width:40%; border:1px solid black">
          <b><![CDATA[Name:]]></b>
          </td>

          <td valign="center" style="text-align:center; width:60%; border:1px solid black">
          <xsl:value-of select="$customDisplayName"/>
          </td>

          </tr>
          </table>
  • The table is displaying one row printing Name along the value of it.
  • customDisplayName is referring to employee name which is being pulled from worksheet
  • “$ “is always used before any fieldID to pull the value of that field in statement.

To write any conditions,

<xsl:choose>
              <xsl:when test = "$customFlag = 'Yes' ">
            $<xsl:value-of select = "format-number(vp-custom-data/vp-custom-field[@id='customField1'], '#,##0.00')"/>
            </xsl:when>
             <xsl:when test="vp-custom-data/vp-custom-field[@id='customPayoutPer'] > 0">
              $<xsl:value-of select="format-number(vp-custom-data/vp-custom-field[@id='customField2'], '#,##0.00')"/>
          </xsl:when>
            <xsl:otherwise>
             $<xsl:value-of select="format-number(vp-custom-data/vp-custom-field[@id='customField3', '#,##0.00')"/>
          </xsl:otherwise>
        </xsl:choose>
  • This code is saying that if there is any custom field as “customFlag” and its value is equal to Yes, it will pull the value of customfield1 and print it
  • If “customFlag”is not equal to Yes and a custom field called “customPaypoutper is greater than 0 then the value of customField2 will be pulled
  • If both the condition is not fulfilled, then customField3 value will be printed

To maintain translation of different language

<xsl:template name="get-month-name">
		<xsl:param name="month"/>
		<xsl:param name="target_locale" select="en_US"/>
		<xsl:choose>
			<xsl:when test="$month = 1">
				<xsl:choose>
					<xsl:when test="$target_locale = 'es_ES'">Enero</xsl:when>
					<xsl:when test="$target_locale = 'pt_BR'">Janeiro</xsl:when>
					<xsl:when test="$target_locale = 'fr_CA'">janvier</xsl:when>
					<xsl:otherwise>Jan</xsl:otherwise>
				</xsl:choose>
			</xsl:when>
			</xsl:choose>
			</xsl:template>
  • The parameter target_locale is used for maintaining translations of different language.

    Conclusion: - 

    Implementing custom statements in sap SuccessFactors is more than a technical upgrade. By utilizing the flexibility of custom statements, organizations can present the compensation data in a way that’s clear, meaningful and aligned with the brand value.

entry.title: Difference and Relationship Between Job Profile Builder and Employee Central in SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Within the SAP SuccessFactors ecosystem, Job Profile Builder (JPB) and Employee Central (EC) play pivotal yet distinct roles. Although they serve different functions, their integration is what enables organizations to manage employee data and talent development as one unified process. Gaining clarity on how these two modules differ, and how they complement each other, is key to unlocking their full value in driving workforce growth and operational efficiency.

 

Relationship and Integration


Despite being separate modules, JPB and EC are tightly interwoven in day-to-day HR operations. Their synchronization ensures consistency across processes, from recruitment to career progression.

  • JPB defines the framework for each role: It outlines job requirements, skills, and expected competencies, creating a standardized structure for positions across the organization. This helps streamline hiring, performance reviews, and career development.
  • EC centralizes employee information: It stores and manages all personal and professional data, such as promotions, transfers, organizational assignments, and historical records. It connects each worker to their specific job role and tracks how those roles evolve over time.
  • How they interact: When an employee takes on a role, EC automatically aligns their personal record with the corresponding profile in JPB. This integration affects not only skills assessments and training assignments but also succession planning and long-term career management.
  • Core to HR digitalization: EC acts as the central repository of workforce data, while JPB provides the talent framework that supports strategic HR planning. Together, they form the backbone of modern, cloud-based HR management.

 

Practical Applications

  1. Recruiting and Onboarding
    Recruiters rely on job profiles designed in JPB to clearly set out expectations in job postings. Once a candidate is hired, their data flows into EC and links automatically to the relevant profile. This connection simplifies onboarding and sets the foundation for growth and performance evaluation.
  2. Performance Management
    During evaluations, managers assess employees against the competencies and responsibilities defined in JPB. Meanwhile, EC records achievements, role changes, and progress, building a complete picture of an employee’s professional journey.
  3. Career and Succession Planning
    JPB highlights the skills and knowledge needed for future leadership roles. In EC, employees can explore career paths, track progress toward next-level positions, and receive learning recommendations that align with their current and target job profiles.

 

Summary


Job Profile Builder (JPB) = Defines the requirements of each role (responsibilities, skills, competencies).

Employee Central (EC) = Holds the information about the employee filling that role (personal data, contracts, history).

By working together, JPB and EC bring structure to both the organization’s needs and the people who meet them. This seamless integration supports a connected HR ecosystem, powering recruitment, development, learning, performance management, and payroll all within one platform.

And here you have a summary table of the differences and complementarities of JPB and EC. 

 

FeatureJob Profile Builder (JPB)Employee Central (EC)
Main PurposeDefine and manage job profiles and their attributes: competencies, skills, responsibilities, families, and roles.Manage employee master data: personal information, contracts, organizational location, hierarchies, payroll.
Data ManagementData related to positions, roles, and organizational descriptions.Data related to people: personal and employment information.
ModularityUsed in Talent modules: Recruiting, Performance, Development, Succession, Learning.Its own module in SuccessFactors (EC), but integrates data for other areas (payroll, compensation, learning).
FocusOrganizational: Structure and content of positions within the company.Individual: Current and historical information for each employee, including change history.

I hope this short post helps shed some light on the fundamental ideas behind two of the most essential elements in SuccessFactors. My goal is to make these core concepts clearer, particularly for those who may be newer to the system or have had only limited hands‑on experience.

entry.title: Scalable Employee Document Repository using nested MDF Objects - Exploring Custom MDF Potential
entry.content:
Overview / Business challenges

The requirement is to store employee documents which are categorized as per the year and document category. There are various solutions available with SAP BTP however, for the clients who do not have BTP License, it could be a challenge.

Also, Manage Documents Functionality cannot be used in this scenario as it comes with following challenges –

  1. It is difficult to manage and maintain document categories under Manage Documents.
  2. The UI of Manage Documents is not very intuitive and user friendly.
  3. There are Data privacy concerns as well under Manage Documents as all the documents will be visible to the employees having access to Manage Documents.

Solution Overview

1. Custom MDF Creation

A MDF Based portlet is built and attached on the employee profile tagged to each employee to store the respective documents. The documents can be added to different years by selecting the year from the dropdown and then adding the documents relevant to that particular year. The documents can be categorized by selected the relevant option from the dropdown of the field – Document Category. The portlet can be permissioned via Role Based Permissions controlling who can view the portlet and can edit/add documents within the same.

The solution details further with the creation of 3 custom MDF object having Parent Child Relationship. Although there is a limitation to have three of more child objects on Custom UI ( 2969227 - MDF Object not appearing in Manage configuration UI ), the arrangement of the objects on the UI as described below helped overcome this challenge.

Details of the objects are as per below:

  • Custom Object 1 – Employee Document Repository (Master Parent Object): The object is created with external code of type User which links the repository to the employees. The object is associated with another custom object – Document Year.

  • Custom Object 2 – Document Year (Child Object): The object is created with external code of type Auto Number and a custom field as picklist to capture the year for the documents. The object is associated with the grandchild custom object – Add Document.

Custom Object 2 – Document Year (Secondary Parent Object):

  • Custom Object 3 – Add Document (Grandchild Object): The object is created with external code of type Auto Number, custom field of type picklist to capture the document category and a custom field of type Attachment. The object is associated with the child custom object – Add Document.

Custom Object 3 – Add Document (Child Object)

The picklist for Document Category can be customized as per client requirements. Broadly, it can have values like Certifications, Dependents, Education, Others etc.

2. Custom UI for the Object

A Custom UI is created based on the Master Parent Object – Employee Document Repository and then added on the people profile under a separate view. The accessibility of the custom MDF portlet on the employee profile can be controlled via Role Based Permissions Framework.

To have better UI Experience, use grouping of fields and custom objects.

Properties for Base Object Group:

Properties for Middle Object Group:

Properties of the child object group:

 

3. Adding Documents on the People Profile

  • Go to Employee Profile and scroll to Employee Document Repository section. Click on the pencil icon next to Document Repository to add/update the documentation.
  • A pop-up window opens which will have the documents segregated based on years in collapsed mode by default.

  • Expand the existing years to view/add/update the documents or click on Add button to add another year for which the documents need to be added.
  1. Expand the Document Details to view the existing document to edit/update.
  2. Click on Add to add new document for the expanded year (i.e., 2024 in this case as per below screenshot)

  • After click on Add button, select the document category from the document and upload the attachment. Click on SAVE.

Note: The Document Category contains basic data as of now which can be extended to have additional values as per the requirement of customer.

  •  Adding a new document year and add documents to that year –

  • After clicking on add – a new collapsed section “Document Repository” is created.

  • Expand the section and select the year from the dropdown:

  •  Selecting the year from the dropdown will update “Document Repository” to the selected year.

Follow the details in step 4 and step 5 to add the document details and click on SAVE.

4. Limitations:

  • The collapsible mode works only in the edit mode. On the employee profile, all the documents will be visible.

  • The documents will be arranged automatically in the order they get added to the portlet and will not get automatically sorted in reverse chronological order. If the records need to be rearranged, it can be done via Manage data > Employee Document Repository > Search by Employee.

5. Value Proposition and Conclusion

To summarize, in order to achieve the document repository, we harnessed the capabilities of Metadata Framework functionality to create three nested MDF objects & created picklists to categorize the documents based on year and document type. The solution is easily scalable not only for document repository but can be referenced for achieving custom solutions having the need for nested MDF objects.

This solution meets the business requirement with the already available functionalities within the standard licensing and hence, does not require additional licenses (for instance SAP BTP) to achieve the same for the basic repository functionality.

entry.title: API Guide about Management Multiple Employment(Concurrent Employment, Global Assignment, Rehire)
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog presents a holistic integration approach to managing SuccessFactors Multiple Employment scenarios. It covers:

  • Adding Concurrent Employment
  • Adding Global Assignment
  • Rehire with New Employment (International Transfer)
  • Rehire with Old Employment
  • Query Multiple Employment(Identify Primary Employment)

The focus here is on the technical implementation via APIs. In a subsequent blog, I will cover the business scenarios with standard operating procedures and integration flows.

Background

When preparing a multiple employment API document for integrating a local HRIS system with the global SAP SuccessFactors HRIS, I realized that there was no comprehensive guide on this subject. Information was scattered across SAP KBAs, official documentation, and blogs, requiring significant effort to test and validate. This blog aims to provide a single reference document, so consultants can avoid piecing together content from multiple sources.
Before diving into the technical details, I recommend reviewing the best practices and implementation Design Principle for SuccessFactors Multiple Employment to build a foundational understanding.

  1. Multiple Employment Blog
  2. IDP for Multiple Employment

Notes

  • The mandatory fields depend on your instance configuration. Adjust payloads according to your actual system settings.
  • I will share in the importable postman json collection, you could import it into Postman for testing.
  • Please pay attentication to "rehire","eventReason","userId" fields and the corresponding value in these API.

1. Add Concurrent Employment

1.1 Generate Concurrent Employment UserId

API Endpoint:
{{demoAPIServer}}/odata/v2/upsert?$format=json
Payload:

{
    "__metadata": {
        "uri": "https://apisalesdemo8.successfactors.com/odata/v2/EmpEmployment",
        "type": "SFOData.EmpEmployment"
    },
    "personIdExternal": "dawang",
    "userId": "dawang-1", //a unique ID, recommended to use a sequence suffix to generate
    "startDate": "/Date(1710508645000)/",
    "originalStartDate": "/Date(1610508645000)/"
}

1.2 Post Job Info for Concurrent Employment

API Endpoint:
{{demoAPIServer}}/odata/v2/upsert?$format=json
Payload:

{
    "__metadata": {
        "uri": "https://apisalesdemo8.successfactors.com/odata/v2/EmpJob",
        "type": "SFOData.EmpJob"
    },
    "seqNumber": "1",
    "userId": "dawang-1", //rehire userId
    "startDate": "/Date(1710508645000)/", //rehire date
    "eventReason": "REH", // The eventReason should belong to "HIRE" event but not "REHIRE" event
    "workscheduleCode": "NORM",
    "jobCode": "50071000",
    "division": "CORP_SVCS",
    "timeTypeProfileCode": "FRA_STD",
    "costCenter": "2200-2200",
    "residentVote": false,
    "fte": "1",
    "payGrade": "GR-12",
    "timeRecordingVariant": "DURATION",
    "managerId": "102005",
    "businessUnit": "CORP",
    "position": "50024034",
    "company": "2200"
}

1.3 Exchange Primary Employment (If Needed)

API Endpoint:
{{demoAPIServer}}/odata/v2/upsert?$format=json
Payload:

{
    "__metadata": {
        "uri": "https://apisalesdemo8.successfactors.com/odata/v2/SecondaryAssignments",
        "type": "SFOData.SecondaryAssignments"
    },
    "externalCode": "dawang",
    "effectiveStartDate": "/Date(1720460800000)/", //the primary assignment exchange effective start date
    "allSfProcesses": {
        "results": [
            {
                "__metadata": {
                    "uri": "https://apisalesdemo8.successfactors.com/odata/v2/SecondaryAssignmentsItem",
                    "type": "SFOData.SecondaryAssignmentsItem"
                },
                "SecondaryAssignments_effectiveStartDate": "/Date(1720460800000)/",
                "SecondaryAssignments_externalCode": "dawang",
                "externalCode": "3f90b5ba81a741ca9a0573180b4a6439",
                "usersSysId": "dawang", //secondary assignment userId, if there exist multiple secondard assignment, then use an arry to include.
                "mdfSystemStatus": "A"
            },
            {
                "__metadata": {
                    "uri": "https://apisalesdemo8.successfactors.com/odata/v2/SecondaryAssignmentsItem",
                    "type": "SFOData.SecondaryAssignmentsItem"
                },
                "SecondaryAssignments_effectiveStartDate": "/Date(1720460800000)/",
                "SecondaryAssignments_externalCode": "dawang",
                "externalCode": "3f90b5ba81a741ca9a0573180b4a6440",
                "usersSysId": "dawang-2", //secondary assignment userId, if there exist multiple secondard assignment, then use an arry to include.
                "mdfSystemStatus": "A"
            }
        ]
    }
}

2. Rehire with New Employment (International Transfer)

2.1 Generate Rehire UserId

API Endpoint:
{{demoAPIServer}}/odata/v2/upsert?$format=json
Payload:

{
    "__metadata": {
        "uri": "https://api44.sapsf.com/odata/v2/EmpEmployment"
    },
    "startDate": "/Date(1710508645000)/", //hire date for additional job
    "personIdExternal": "dawang",
    "isRehire": true, //rehire identifier
    "userId": "dawang-1" //new generated userId
}

2.2 Post Job Info for Rehire

API Endpoint:
{{demoAPIServer}}/odata/v2/upsert?$format=json
Payload:

{
    "__metadata": {
        "uri": "{{demoAPIServer}}/odata/v2/EmpJob",
        "type": "SFOData.EmpJob"
    },
    "seqNumber": "1",
    "userId": "dawang-1",
    "eventReason": "REHIRE",  // The eventReason should belong to "HIRE" event but not "REHIRE" event
    "startDate": "/Date(1710374400000)/", //Rehire Date
    "employeeClass": null,
    "businessUnit": "BU110",
    "employmentType": "38905",
    "costCenter": "203020",
    "standardHours": "9",
    "regularTemp": "38898",
    "jobCode": "000048",
    "customString3": "sub team01",
    "workPeriod": "38916",
    "customString12": "38932",
    "company": "300",
    "location": "HQ",
    "position": "10000103",
    "department": "35MO"
}

Note: The main difference compared to "Add Concurrent Employment"" is the field "isRehire": true and "eventReason": "REHIRE".

3. Add Global Assignment

3.1 Generate Global Assignment UserId

API Endpoint:
{{demoAPIServer}}/odata/v2/upsert?$format=json
Payload:

{
	"__metadata":{
		"uri":"EmpGlobalAssignment"
	},
	"assignmentType":"8440", //Long Term or Short Term, Check the picklist option Id of picklist "global_assignment_type"
	"startDate":"/Date(1710508645000)/",
	"plannedEndDate":"/Date(1720508645000)/",
	"personIdExternal":"100097",
	"userId":"100097-2" ////new generated userId
}

3.2 Post Job Info for Global Assignment Employment

 

API Endpoint:
{{demoAPIServer}}/odata/v2/upsert?$format=json
Payload:

{
    "__metadata": {
        "uri": "https://apisalesdemo8.successfactors.com/odata/v2/EmpJob",
        "type": "SFOData.EmpJob"
    },
    "seqNumber": "1",
    "userId": "100097-2",
    "startDate": "/Date(1710508645000)/", //Global Assignment Start Date
    "eventReason": "ADD_GA", //The event reason should be standard ADD_GA.
    "employeeClass": null,
    "businessUnit": "BU110",
    "employmentType": "38905",
    "costCenter": "203020",
    "standardHours": "9",
    "regularTemp": "38898",
    "jobCode": "000048",
    "customString3": "sub team01",
    "workPeriod": "38916",
    "customString12": "38932",
    "company": "300",
    "location": "HQ",
    "position": "10000103",
    "department": "35MO"
}

Note: Unlike the UI, the API will not automatically handle the “end global assignment” and "back global assignment" event. You must execute it in API additionally.

4. Rehire with Old Employment

4.1 Post Job Info for Rehire with Old Employment

API Endpoint:
{{demoAPIServer}}/odata/v2/upsert?$format=json
Payload:

{
    "__metadata": {
        "uri": "{{demoAPIServer}}/odata/v2/EmpJob",
        "type": "SFOData.EmpJob"
    },
    "seqNumber": "1",
    "userId": "00006003551",
    "eventReason": "REH", // The eventReason should belong to "REHIRE" event but not "HIRE" event
    "startDate": "/Date(1723902400000)/", //Rehire Date
    "employeeClass": null,
    "businessUnit": "BU110",
    "employmentType": "38905",
    "costCenter": "203020",
    "standardHours": "9",
    "regularTemp": "38898",
    "jobCode": "000048",
    "customString3": "sub team01",
    "workPeriod": "38916",
    "customString12": "38932",
    "company": "300",
    "location": "HQ",
    "position": "10000103",
    "department": "35MO"
}

Notes:

  1. A termination record must already exist.
  2. Once the job info record is inserted, the hire date in employment details is automatically updated.

Multiple Employment Data Structure

You can query all multiple employment scenarios with a single API call.
API Endpoint:
{{demoAPIServer}}/odata/v2/PerPerson?$format=json&$expand=secondaryAssignmentsNav/allSfProcesses,employmentNav/empGlobalAssignmentNav,employmentNav/jobInfoNav/userNav&$select=personIdExternal,createdDateTime,perPersonUuid,personId,secondaryAssignmentsNav/externalCode,secondaryAssignmentsNav/effectiveStartDate,secondaryAssignmentsNav/effectiveEndDate,secondaryAssignmentsNav/mdfSystemStatus,secondaryAssignmentsNav/allSfProcesses/SecondaryAssignments_effectiveStartDate,secondaryAssignmentsNav/allSfProcesses/SecondaryAssignments_externalCode,secondaryAssignmentsNav/allSfProcesses/externalCode,secondaryAssignmentsNav/allSfProcesses/usersSysId,secondaryAssignmentsNav/allSfProcesses/mdfSystemStatus,employmentNav/personIdExternal,employmentNav/userId,employmentNav/endDate,employmentNav/employmentId,employmentNav/bonusPayExpirationDate,employmentNav/salaryEndDate,employmentNav/seniorityDate,employmentNav/benefitsEndDate,employmentNav/lastDateWorked,employmentNav/assignmentIdExternal,employmentNav/startDate,employmentNav/prevEmployeeId,employmentNav/payrollEndDate,employmentNav/assignmentClass,employmentNav/empGlobalAssignmentNav/userId,employmentNav/jobInfoNav/endDate,employmentNav/empGlobalAssignmentNav/assignmentClass,employmentNav/jobInfoNav/emplStatus,employmentNav/empGlobalAssignmentNav/assignmentIdExternal,employmentNav/jobInfoNav/eventReason,employmentNav/empGlobalAssignmentNav/assignmentType,employmentNav/jobInfoNav/position,employmentNav/empGlobalAssignmentNav/startDate,employmentNav/empGlobalAssignmentNav/personIdExternal,employmentNav/jobInfoNav/seqNumber,employmentNav/jobInfoNav/startDate,employmentNav/jobInfoNav/userId,employmentNav/jobInfoNav/userNav/isPrimaryAssignment&$filter=personIdExternal in '27000005'

Sample Response:

{
    "d": {
        "results": [
            {
                "__metadata": {
                    "uri": "https://apisalesdemo8.successfactors.com/odata/v2/PerPerson('104006')",
                    "type": "SFOData.PerPerson"
                },
                "personIdExternal": "104006",
                "createdDateTime": "/Date(1441583133000+0000)/",
                "personId": "514",
                "perPersonUuid": "081A2D5745B34F50ADE137D29CBCDD64",
                "secondaryAssignmentsNav": {
                    "results": []
                },
                "employmentNav": {
                    "results": [

                                            "__metadata": {
                                                "uri": "https://apisalesdemo8.successfactors.com/odata/v2/User('27000005')",
                                                "type": "SFOData.User"
                                            },
                                            "isPrimaryAssignment": true
                                        }
                                    }
                                ]
                            }
                        }
                    ]
                }
            }
        ]
    }
}

Query Primary and Secondary Employment

In addition to the solution to Differentiating primary from secondary employment during concurrent employment replication in SAP Help recommendations, you can use the isPrimaryAssignment field in the User Entity to identify primary employment.
Notes:

  1. isPrimaryAssignment becomes false for all inactive employment records.
  2. This field is not reportable in Story or Canvas reports. As a workaround, you can use Integration Center to replicate it into a custom fields in a reportable table.
  3. Alternatively, compare the userId in SecondaryAssignmentsItem with the userId in the main record. If they do not match, the record is primary. However, this approach only works reliably for up to two employments.

Conclusion

A strong understanding of the data structure is crucial to mastering these APIs. The key principles are:

  1. Use EmpEmployment to generate a unique UserId.
  2. Use EmpJob to create the employment details.
    With these APIs, you now have a complete toolkit for handling multiple employment in SAP SuccessFactors.

In the next post, I will cover business scenarios and standard operating procedures for these integration scenarios.
Follow me here or on LinkedIn for updates.

entry.title: SAP BTP Administration and Security Enhancement Blogs by Sushil Gupta
entry.content:
🌟Consolidated Guide to My SAP Community Blogs

Hare Krishna 🙏. This blog series, published on SAP Community, brings together structured guidance and practical insights on SAP BTP Administration ⚙️, BTP Security Enhancements 🔐, SuccessFactors Integrations 🔗, IAS & IPS 🛡️, AI & Digital Transformation 🤖, and Project-Specific Scenarios 📂.

Over time, many professionals (SAP Community members) reached out with questions and requested a consolidated resource. This series makes it easy to explore step by step, learn from real-world examples, and apply solutions effectively.

💡Giving Back to the Community
This series is my way of giving back to the SAP community — consolidating practical tips, configurations, and hands-on insights to help anyone explore and implement BTP, SuccessFactors, and security solutions confidently.

Quick Tip !

I have used an SAP BTP Trial account to create the scenarios for all these blogs, so everyone will be able to perform hands-on exercises by following the steps shared in the blogs by just requesting SAP BTP Free trial account.

🌟Highlights (Most Popular)

🔥IAS Integration with SuccessFactors – Part 1 (Initial setup, tenant connection)

(72,800+ 👀| ⭐ 57+ | 💬 21+)
Kick-off to my most popular SuccessFactors integration series, explaining IAS tenant connection and initial setup in a step-by-step manner.
Helps consultants and admins set up secure integration as the foundation for further configurations.

🔗Read the blog

🔥IAS Integration with SuccessFactors – Part 2 (User sync with IPS)

(40,700+ 👀| ⭐ 24+ | 💬34+)
Explains how to sync users between SuccessFactors and IAS using IPS with automated jobs.
One of the most frequently asked scenarios in real projects.

🔗Read the blog

⭐Why Identity Authentication is Required for SuccessFactors

(26,000+ 👀| ⭐ 41+ | 💬12+)
Discusses why IAS is mandatory for SuccessFactors from a compliance and SSO perspective.
Helps customers understand business and technical benefits of IAS adoption.

🔗Read the blog

🔧⚙️SAP BTP Administration

This section covers practical guidance for managing and configuring SAP BTP environments. From trial tenant SSO setups to transport management, it provides step-by-step instructions and real-world examples for admins and consultants. 🖥️📦

🔑BTP Trial Platform SSO – Game Changer for New Customers & POCs

Explains how to enable single sign-on (SSO) for BTP trial accounts using IAS.
A must-read for beginners experimenting with POCs and demos.

🔗Read the blog

📦Enhancing Security in SAP Cloud Transport Management in SAP BTP - 1

Covers basics of SAP Cloud Transport Management (TMS) and node-based privileges.
Introduces how to secure transport processes in BTP.

🔗Read the blog

📦🔐Enhancing Security in SAP Cloud Transport Management in SAP BTP - 2

Deep dive into security enhancements in TMS with granular controls.
Shares lessons learned from real-world SAP project usage.

🔗Read the blog

✨🔮The Magic of Attributes in SAP IAS: Default vs Enrich Assertion

Compares default vs enrich assertion attributes in IAS.
Shows practical examples and when each should be used in integrations.

🔗Read the blog

🔐🛡️ SAP BTP Security Enhancement

Focuses on strengthening security across SAP BTP and integrations. Includes token-based authentication, certificate-based IAS enhancements, and transitioning from API Access Plans to BTP CLI credentials, helping ensure robust, enterprise-ready security. 🔒⚡

🌉Strengthening SAP BTP Security: SSO with Cloud Connector Using Token-Based Auth 

Replaces legacy SUSER approach with token-based authentication.
Improves hybrid security between on-prem and BTP systems.

🔗Read the blog

⚡Evolving Security in SAP BTP – Goodbye APIAccess Plan, Hello BTP CLI

Details SAP’s shift from API Access Plans to BTP CLI credentials.
Highlights how this change enhances security and automation.

🔗Read the blog

📜🔏Enhancing Security in Identity Authentication Service (IAS) with Certificate-Based Authentication

Moves beyond client ID/secret to certificate-based IAS authentication.
Demonstrates stronger, enterprise-ready security for identity services.

🔗Read the blog

🔗💼SAP BTP Integrations (SuccessFactors IAS Series)

Covers end-to-end IAS integration with SuccessFactors, from initial setup and tenant connection to user provisioning via IPS and activation/testing. Designed as a sequential, practical guide for consultants and admins implementing secure SSO and identity management. 🧩🔄

📘IAS Integration with SuccessFactors – Part 0 (Overview & Basics)

Introduces IAS, SSO concepts, and integration prerequisites.
Sets the stage for the full configuration series.

🔗Read the blog

🔥IAS Integration with SuccessFactors – Part 1 (Initial setup, tenant connection)

Provides step-by-step initial tenant connection setup.
Forms the base for all future IAS-SF integration.

🔗Read the blog

📘IAS Integration with SuccessFactors – Part 2 (User sync with IPS)

Shows how to sync users between SF and IAS via IPS.
Covers attribute mapping and automated provisioning.

🔗Read the blog

📘IAS Integration with SuccessFactors – Part 3 (Activation & Testing)

Focuses on activating the IAS integration.
Explains testing approaches to validate successful SSO.

🔗Read the blog

⚙️Identity Authentication Service(IAS) Configuration approach with SAP SuccessFactors 

Presents different IAS configuration approaches.
Helps choose best-fit setups for project needs.

🔗Read the blog

💡IAS integration with SAP Success Factors Application - Tips and Tricks

Summarizes practical advice, common pitfalls, and quick fixes.
Ideal for consultants working on tight project timelines.

🔗Read the blog

⭐Why Identity authentication is required for SAP SuccessFactors Application

Explains compliance, SSO, and security benefits of IAS adoption.
Helps customers justify IAS in their landscapes.

🔗Read the blog

📂📝Project-Specific Scenarios

Highlights complex, real-world scenarios encountered in projects. Includes advanced IPS provisioning cases, EC ↔ Payroll integration, and phased rollouts, giving readers insights on how to handle exceptions and optimize deployments. 🔄👥

🔄Integrating IPS with SuccessFactors (project-specific)

Addresses advanced provisioning scenarios with IPS.
Covers tricky cases like password migrations.

🔗Read the blog

👥💰Employee Central ↔ Payroll Integration (technical perspective)

Explains EC ↔ ECP integration options.
Compares direct vs IAS-based connectivity in practice.

🔗Read the blog

🎯Smarter SF Provisioning (phased rollouts with scoping filters)

Shows how to implement phased provisioning using scoping filters.
Reduces risks compared to big-bang rollouts.

🔗Read the blog

☁️💡SAP HANA Cloud & 🤖 AI

This section explores how SAP HANA Cloud enables modern, scalable cloud architectures and how AI tools can be applied to transform business processes. It includes practical insights on migration strategies and real-world examples of intelligent automation to help you leverage SAP technologies effectively. 

🚀Migrating to SAP HANA Cloud: A Business Transformation Journey

Describes challenges and strategy for migration to HANA Cloud.
Highlights benefits for scalability and modernization.

🔗Read the blog

🛒🤖End-to-End Business Transformation with SAP AI Tools: A Practical Example

Uses grocery business as an example of AI in action.
Demonstrates how SAP AI tools transform operations.

🔗Read the blog

🎓🏆Learning & Growth

Provides guidance on upskilling with SAP Learnings, earning digital badges, and tracking Records of Achievement. Encourages readers to continuously develop expertise and showcase verified skills to enhance their professional growth. 📚🏅

📚Upskill with SAP Learnings (badges, RoA)

Shows how to earn SAP digital badges and Records of Achievement for free.
Encourages professionals to showcase verified skills.

🔗Read the blog

🌟Conclusion

This series is a consolidated resource of my SAP insights and experiences. Stay tuned for more updates, blogs, and practical tips to help the community explore and learn.

entry.title: Steps for Generating the SAML Assertion to read the data from the Successfactors using IAS
entry.content:
SAP recommends using OAuth 2.0 authentication for API integrations, as HTTP Basic Authentication is deprecated.

In the context of SuccessFactors OData APIs, OAuth 2.0 authentication relies on the SAML 2.0 Bearer Assertion flow. This approach requires an external Identity Provider (IdP), such as SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS), to generate a signed SAML assertion. That assertion is then exchanged for an OAuth access token, which is used to authenticate API requests to the SAP SuccessFactors system.

Prerequisites

Before implementing the flow, ensure that:

  • SAP SuccessFactors is federated with SAP IAS.

  • A SuccessFactors API user is created, using the same username in both SuccessFactors and IAS.

  • A copy of the SAP IAS signing certificate is available (to be uploaded to SuccessFactors for trust configuration).

Steps :

Please follow the steps below to configure and use it seamlessly . 

Steps for Generating the SAML Assertion to read the data from the Successfactors using IAS for Integration.

  1. Take the SSO certificate from the IAS tenant

Go to Application and resources and choose tenant Settings:

Click on the Single Sign-on Tab and navigate the SAML 2.O Configuration:

Click on the signing Certificates and copy the certificate to register the OAUTH application in Manage OAuth2 Client Applications in Successfactors.

Click on the Binoculars and copy the certificate to use it while registering the Application in Successfactors.

  1. Login to SuccessFactors and go to the Manage OAuth2 Client Applications in Successfactors.

Name

Value

Company

Successfactors instance company id

Application Name

Any Name which is relevant for your integration

Description

Any description

Application URL

Give the application url for which you are going to use this set up.

Bind to users

SFADMIN (or any other API users having admin permissions)

x.509 certificate

IAS tenant setting Signing certificate copy and paste here

API key

It will generate automatically, and we will use it at later point of time so keep it handy

 

  1. Go to IAS and navigate to the application and Resources and choose application.

Create two applications here in IAS system.

  1. OIDC to generate the IAS token having name OIDCTOKEN
  2. SuccessFactors OAuth Integration for generating the token for Successfactors to read the SF data.

 

  1. Go the applications and create and name the applications as OIDCTOKEN.

Application is created as shown below:

Configure the OIDC application to allow password and token exchange: For that you need to click on the OpenID connect configuration.

Keep the grant Types as password and Token exchange (RFC 8693) and save it.

Create secret for the OIDC application and Copy Client ID and Client Secret for later use

Scroll down, copy the client and add the client secret as shown below:

Click on ADD and use the below details to configure and save it.

Client ID and secret will be generated, kindly keep it for later use.

Example of client id and secret!

Client ID: 8b351919-d729-4c6e-ab73-f78d123456

Client Secret: VHJOqEJu4IA2hyA[KzUnm12hr58754

After clicking on OK.

  1. Under Applications & Resources > Applications > Create, create a new application for SF with SAML 2.0 as Protocol Type and the application Name will be SuccessFactors OAuth Integration

Under SAML 2.0 Configuration tab, set the Name field/Entity ID to any you wish and add the SF token endpoint (https:///oauth/token) . In our case the token URL will be https://api2preview.sapsf.eu/oauth/token

NOTE: Do not use existing SF application because special settings are required for OAUTH that is why we are creating a new application here.

Under Subject Name Identifier tab, select Basic Configuration option and set the basic attribute to Login Name:
